questions.question: What is the primary function of the first line of defense in the immune system?
options: To provide physical and chemical barriers that prevent pathogen entry
To deploy white blood cells that actively attack invading pathogens
To generate specific antibodies that target and neutralize viral particles
To initiate fever and systemic inflammation responses after infection
questions.explanation: The first line consists of innate, non-specific barriers that prevent microorganisms from entering the body in the first place.

questions.question: Which of these serves as a primary physical barrier in the first line of defense?
options: The skin
Stomach acid (gastric juice)
Plasma-derived antibodies
Active phagocytic cells
questions.explanation: Intact skin provides a continuous, waterproof physical barrier that most pathogens cannot penetrate when healthy and unbroken.

questions.question: What is the specific role of mucous membranes in the body's defense strategy?
options: To trap pathogens in sticky secretions and move them out of the body
To synthesize specific antibodies against common environmental invaders
To directly engulf and digest bacteria through cellular phagocytosis
To trigger a localized inflammatory response to recruit immune cells
questions.explanation: Mucus produced by mucous membranes traps microorganisms, and cilia or peristalsis move them out (coughing, sneezing, swallowing).

questions.question: How does stomach acid effectively act as a chemical barrier?
options: Its highly acidic pH destroys most ingested pathogenic microorganisms
It facilitates the production of antibodies against food-borne bacteria
It acts as a chemical signal to attract white blood cells to the stomach
It chemically neutralizes all toxic substances found in ingested food
questions.explanation: Gastric juice has a pH of 1.5-3.5, which destroys most bacteria and viruses that enter through food and drink.

questions.question: Which protective enzyme is naturally found in human tears and saliva?
options: Lysozyme
Histamine
Agglutinin
Interferon
questions.explanation: Lysozyme is an enzyme that breaks down bacterial cell walls, providing chemical protection in body secretions.

questions.question: How does the skin's normal flora (resident bacteria) contribute to the first line of defense?
options: It competes with foreign pathogens for physical space and vital nutrients
It produces specialized antibodies that neutralize invading pathogens
It actively hunts and kills all foreign bacteria entering the environment
It triggers the nervous system to signal white blood cells to attack
questions.explanation: Commensal bacteria occupy niches and consume resources, making it difficult for pathogenic bacteria to establish infections.

questions.question: What occurs physiologically when the first line of defense is successfully breached?
options: The second line of defense (innate internal immunity) is activated
The body immediately begins the rapid production of memory B cells
The entire immune system undergoes a temporary shutdown
The body relies exclusively on a fever response to handle the breach
questions.explanation: If pathogens get past physical/chemical barriers, non-specific internal defenses (phagocytes, inflammation, fever) become activated.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of the first-line defense mechanism?
options: The production of specific memory B cells
The acidic pH levels found on the skin and in the stomach
The production of mucus within the respiratory and digestive tracts
The mechanical flushing action of tears, sweat, and urine
questions.explanation: Memory B cells are part of the specific adaptive (third line) immunity, developing after exposure to a pathogen.

questions.question: Why are sebaceous (oil) glands critical for maintaining skin-based defense?
options: They secrete lipids that inhibit the growth of many bacteria and fungi
They secrete a layer of antibodies that coats the epidermal surface
They actively recruit beneficial bacteria to the skin surface
They are primarily responsible for the skin's role in thermoregulation
questions.explanation: Sebum creates an acidic environment (pH 3-5) on the skin surface that inhibits the growth of many pathogens.

questions.question: How do cilia in the respiratory tract assist in protecting the lungs?
options: They move in coordinated waves to sweep mucus and trapped particles upward
They secrete antimicrobial chemicals directly into the alveolar sacs
They function as cellular receptors that engulf inhaled viral particles
They transmit electrical signals to the brain to initiate coughing
questions.explanation: Ciliated epithelial cells line the respiratory tract, constantly moving mucus toward the throat to be swallowed or expelled.
